title: Data Fetching
description: In Nuxt we have 2 ways of getting data from an API. We can use the fetch method or the asyncData method.

children.value: In Nuxt we have 2 ways of getting data from an API. We can use the fetch method or the asyncData method.
Nuxt supports traditional Vue patterns for loading data in your client-side app, such as fetching data in a component's
hook. Universal apps, however, need to use Nuxt-specific hooks to be able to render data during server-side rendering. This allows your page to render with all of its required data present.
Nuxt has two hooks for asynchronous data loading:
. This hook can only be placed on
, this hook does not display a loading placeholder during client-side rendering: instead, this hook blocks route navigation until it is resolved, displaying a page error if it fails.
(Nuxt 2.12+). This hook can be placed on any component, and provides shortcuts for rendering loading states (during client-side rendering) and errors.
These hooks can be used with
for making requests to HTTP APIs. More information about these libraries, such as guides for configuring authentication headers, can be found in their respective documentation.
inside a mixin and also have it defined in a component/page, the mixin function will be overwritten instead of called.

is a hook called during server-side rendering after the component instance is created, and on the client when navigating. The fetch hook should return a promise (whether explicitly, or implicitly using
On the server, before the initial page is rendered
On the client, some time after the component is mounted

, the fetch hook is only called during page generation, and the result is then cached for use on the client. To avoid cache conflicts, it may be necessary to specify a name for your component, or alternatively provide a unique fetchKey implementation.
Within the fetch hook, you will have access to the component instance via

. Then the data that comes from the fetch can be assigned to these properties.

If there is an error when fetching data, the normal Nuxt error page won't be loaded - and you should not use the Nuxt
. Instead, you will need to handle it within your component using
and show an error message if there is an error fetching the data.

is another hook for universal data fetching. Unlike
, which requires you to set properties on the component instance (or dispatch Vuex actions) to save your async state,

. This means that no "loading placeholder" is visible during client-side transitions (although the
can be used to indicate a loading state to the user). Nuxt will instead wait for the

This hook can only be used for page-level components. Unlike
as its argument. You can use it to fetch some data and Nuxt will automatically shallow merge the returned object with the component data.

which we recommend for fetching data from an API.
Because components do not have an
method, you cannot directly fetch async data server side within a component. In order to get around this limitation you have three basic options:
that is available in Nuxt 2.12 and later versions.

hook and set data properties when loaded.
Downside: Won't work for server side rendering.
Make the API call in the
method of the page component and pass the data as props to the sub components. Server rendering will work fine.
